head.title: Web Site Offers Cartoons That Interact, With Feeling

hedline.hl1: Web Site Offers Cartoons That Interact, With Feeling

abstract.p: Zoesis Studios is starting Web site for interactive cartoon characters imbued with behavior that mimics human emotion; eventually hopes to create new medium of interactive entertainment parallel to television; drawing (M)

block.p: In an effort to fuse entertainment, education and artificial intelligence, a company in Newton, Mass., is starting a Web site of interactive cartoon characters imbued with behavior that mimics human emotion.
The company, Zoesis Studios, is seeking to eventually create a new medium of interactive entertainment parallel to television.

In an effort to fuse entertainment, education and artificial intelligence, a company in Newton, Mass., is starting a Web site of interactive cartoon characters imbued with behavior that mimics human emotion.
The company, Zoesis Studios, is seeking to eventually create a new medium of interactive entertainment parallel to television.

Zoesis was founded in 1996 by Joseph Bates, a Carnegie Mellon University computer scientist who develops interactive dramas, an area of artificial intelligence research that tries to create fantasy worlds and characters with whom humans can interact.
The site, www.thelivingletters .com, is scheduled to go online today.

The service, which will be offered free and can be accessed with a Windows-based personal computer, will present young Web users with two cartoon-style characters with whom they can interact by using their mouse as a pointer.

The two characters, Otto and Iris, will exhibit behaviors like fear of the dark, giggling when ''tickled'' by a user's mouse and a variety of facial expressions. The characters can play tag with a computer user in one scene, or sing in response to a user acting as ''conductor'' wielding the mouse as a baton.
At some time, the company said, a ''villain'' will be created to help build a story line and some tension into the experience.

Zoesis has initial backing from Fujitsu Ltd., the Japanese consumer electronics giant. Fujitsu has previously financed research on the so-called virtual worlds, which permit users to move around in fantasy worlds, represented by figures known as avatars.
But the Zoesis project is unrelated to that work. Rather, it is the outgrowth of research that Mr. Bates first did with several other members of the start-up at Carnegie Mellon over the last decade.
Known as the Oz Project, the research tried to use artificial intelligence techniques to create a new medium by blending characters, presentation and drama.
''This is broadly an extension that was started in the 1980's on behavior-based robots,'' Mr. Bates said.
The group has worked at creating software ''agents'' whose behavior appears to be goal-based and who can even be imbued with emotional qualities.
Researchers at other academic centers like the M.I.T. Media Laboratory and Stanford University have long worked on similar projects.

Barbara Hayes-Roth, a Stanford artificial intelligence researcher, has also founded a company, Extempo Systems Inc., to develop interactive software agents. Extempo has developed its agents for Internet customer service applications, in which, for instance, a character might answer questions from computer users.
Some social scientists and industry executives say that interactive drama has the potential to replace the television sitcom as an entertainment medium.
Mr. Bates said he believed that such a transition was possible, but he was not certain how quickly the interactive entertainment medium might evolve.
''It's not clear what will make this more compelling than sitcoms,'' he said, ''but certainly if you have character and story you're in the right ballpark.''
